title: Slow Looking: Antique Arms Then and Now (April 7)
title_display: Slow Looking: Antique Arms Then and Now
hero_caption: Pair of Flintlock Pistols, 1660/70. Dutch, Maastricht. George F. Harding Collection.
short_description: Join the conversation as we consider how we perceive weaponry from faraway times and places, as well as how we experience them today.
list_description: Join the conversation as we consider how we perceive weaponry from faraway times and places, as well as how we experience them today.
description:
Join the conversation as Jonathan Tavares, curator of Applied Arts of Europe, and Sam Ramos, director of Gallery Activation, lead a tour of the Art Institute’s spectacular and complicated collection of antique firearms. Learn about the mechanisms and craft of antique firearms and the habits and culture of collecting, while enjoying a close look at rare objects in the collection. 

This participatory conversation will invite observations, questions, and reflections that will inform how we perceive weaponry from faraway times and places, as well as how we experience them today.

If you have any questions about programming, please reach out to museum-programs@artic.edu. For questions related to accessibility accommodations, please email access@artic.edu. 

Please note that in-person tours may be canceled or postponed due to unforeseen circumstances.

Program begins promptly at 2:00.
